courses.name: Topics In Plant Science - Biological/Physical/Mathematics
courses.description: Initial offering of a course(s) in a specific subject matter area. Offered when proposed by a faculty member in that area of expertise.

courses.name: Plant Science Orientation
courses.description: Introduction to perspectives, comprehensiveness, and current issues in the plant sciences. Involves independent learning, faculty interviews, and oral and written communication about agronomy, horticulture, entomology, and plant pathology.

courses.name: World Food and You
courses.description: (same as F_S 1020). Basic scientific principles involved in production agriculture, food processing, marketing and consumption. Evaluation and understanding of current agriculture issues that affect human foods and required nutrients.

courses.name: Career Development
courses.description: Introductory course for students planning a career in plant sciences. Includes an overview of each emphasis area, as well as development of professional skills required for a successful career. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: People, Plants and the Environment
courses.description: Exploration of the science and niche relationships that exist between people, plants, animals, and the environment.  Emphasis placed on urban vs. rural culture, the impact on production agriculture and the world food supply.

courses.name: Topics in Plant Science - Biological/Physical/Mathematics
courses.description: Initial offering of a course(s) in a specific subject matter area. Offered when proposed by a faculty member in that area of expertise.

courses.name: Environmental Horticulture
courses.description: Investigate interrelationships between plants and the environment.  Special emphasis placed on improving homeowners' environmental stewardship and their knowledge of sustainable practices.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Introduction to Soils
courses.description: (same as SOIL 2100). Introduction to soil sciences with emphasis placed on physical, biological, and chemical properties and application to land use, plant growth and environmental problems.

courses.name: Plants and their Cultivation
courses.description: Principles of plant growth with emphasis on anatomy,  physiology, and response to environmental factors. Production and protection of economically important crop and horticulture species.

courses.name: Plant Structure and Function
courses.description: Introduction to plant anatomy;physiology; how plant structures and processes are involved in growth/development.  Labs explore photosynthesis, mineral nutrition, water relations, growth, and hormonal regulation.

courses.name: Plants for Interior Design
courses.description: Identification, culture and uses of plants adaptable to or capable of becoming acclimated to interior environments.

courses.name: Grapes and Wines of the World
courses.description: (same as F_S 2195). Explores the world of wine through study of viticultural principles and practices, wine styles, classifying wine, the winemaking process and New World and Old World wine regions. Learn wine tasting skills and experience wines from around the world. World wine consumption, social and physical health benefits of moderate wine consumption.

courses.name: Ornamental Woody Plants
courses.description: Identification and evaluation of trees and shrubs for landscape use.

courses.name: Ornamental Herbaceous Plants
courses.description: Annuals, biennials, perennials, ground covers, and bulbs; their identification, nomenclature classification, culture and use.

courses.name: Introduction to Floral Design
courses.description: Introduction to the basics of floral design with special emphasis on design mechanics, flower processing, care and handling.  Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: Some sections of this course may be restricted to Plant Science Majors Only and/or students with 75 credit hours or less

courses.name: Everyday Floral Design
courses.description: Intermediate floral design course expanding skills from introductory floral design with emphasis on the elements and principles of design.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Landscape Graphic Communication
courses.description: Landscape design is a blend of art and science. This course is designed to help students expand their artistic skills, including graphic communications. Topics included to achieve this goal are drawing mediums and techniques, coloring mediums and techniques, symbol usage, and elevation drawings. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Landscape Site Analysis
courses.description: In order to effectively design what a site can become a landscape designer must first be able to accurately see what it is. This course presents a detailed look at obtaining, calculating, and manipulating a site's topography and features while offering a glimpse into the methods and means required for implementation of the final landscape design. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Landscape Design
courses.description: An introduction into the processes, principles, and practices of landscape design, this course begins with site analysis and moves through the drawing and presentation of your landscape concepts.

courses.name: Insects in the Environment
courses.description: Ways in which insects are adapted for life in particular environments, basics of morphology, taxonomy; how important insect pests affect food and crop production, and principles of control.

courses.name: Topics in Plant Science - Biological/Physical/Mathematics
courses.description: Initial offering of a course(s) in a specific subject matter area. Offered when proposed by a faculty member in that area of expertise.

courses.name: Horticultural Drainage and Irrigation Systems
courses.description: This course is designed to provide practical knowledge of drainage and irrigation systems for golf courses, sports fields, lawns, landscapes, greenhouses, nurseries and vineyards. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Undergraduate Seminar in Plant Science
courses.description: Discussion of assigned or selected topics in Plant Science, including participation in a panel debate and individual seminar oral presentations.

courses.name: Principles of Weed Science
courses.description: Introduction to principles of weed growth, reproduction, and impact on human activities. Discussion of weed control techniques and technology, weed identification, and developing weed management strategies.

courses.name: Genetics of Agricultural Plants and Animals
courses.description: (same as AN_SCI 3213). Concepts of molecular, transmission, and population and quantitative genetics. Emphasis given to breeding and biotechnological applications in plant and animal agriculture.
courses.prerequisites: MATH 1100 and one of the following:  BIO_SC 1100 (or F_W 1100) or BIO_SC 1200 or BIO_SC 1500.

courses.name: Special Occasion Floral Design
courses.description: Advanced floral design course with emphasis in silk décor, sympathy design and public ceremony design.  Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: PLNT_S 2220 and PLNT_S 2221 with grade of B or above in both

courses.name: Wedding Floral Design
courses.description: Advanced floral design course with emphasis in wedding floral design and personal pieces design.  Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: PLNT_S 2220 and PLNT_S 2221 with grade of B or above in both

courses.name: Retail Floral Management
courses.description: Course focusing on all areas of retail floral management: business finance, marketing, products and services, employee management, and customer service.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Plant Breeding and Genetics
courses.description: Mendelian genetic principles and related genetic developments applicable in plant breeding. Discussion of established and new plant breeding procedures applicable to cultivar development.

courses.name: Plant Propagation
courses.description: Principles and practices of propagation of horticultural plants.
courses.prerequisites: One of the following: PLNT_S 2075, BIO_SC 1200, or BIO_SC 1500 or Instructor's consent.

courses.name: Plant Propagation - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Principles and practices of propagation of horticultural plants.
courses.prerequisites: One of the following: PLNT_S 2075, BIO_SC 1200, or BIO_SC 1500 or Instructor's consent.

courses.name: Principles of Viticulture I
courses.description: (same as F_S 3240). Grapevine growth, development, selection, propagation, training systems, pruning, and harvesting; vineyard site selection, design, and development. Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: F_S 1010 and F_S 2195 or PLNT_S 2195; or PLNT_S 2100; or PLNT_S 2110; or PLNT_S 2125

courses.name: Green Industry Bidding
courses.description: Principles of interpreting drawings, estimating labor, equipment, materials and other costs and recordkeeping for preparation of competitive green industry bids.  Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: Plant Science major and completion of 30 credit hours

courses.name: Arboriculture and Pruning
courses.description: Concepts for establishment and management of urban trees.  Emphasis on planting, fertilization, pruning, disease, hazard assessment and components of a municipal trees ordinance.

courses.name: Landscape AutoCAD
courses.description: AutoCAD is the most widely utilized computer aided drafting software program in the professional landscape design industry. This course will teach students how to utilize AutoCAD to transform their landscape design skills into a digital format and investigate the benefits of utilizing technology as a design tool. We will also explore other industry utilized software, and their functionality, with focus on landscape design and presentation. Additional software will include, but not be limited to, AutoDesk Revit; Adobe Photoshop; and Sketchup. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Greenhouse Management
courses.description: Greenhouse design, environmental control and equipment. Practices associated with plant nutrition management, greenhouse pest control, postproduction handling and marketing of greenhouse crops, and greenhouse management are also covered.

courses.name: Forage Crops
courses.description: An introduction to principle forage crops, including identification, anatomy, physiology, and growth characteristics.  Pasture production and management, grazing systems, and forage preservation and utilization will also be covered.
courses.prerequisites: PLNT_S 2125 or AN_SCI 3232 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Grain Crops
courses.description: Lecture and discussion covering production and utilization, plus growth and development of a wide range of grain crops, including Missouri crops. Problem solving tasks include agronomics, economics and environmental factors.

courses.name: Introductory Turfgrass Management
courses.description: Characteristics of turf materials, principles of establishment and maintenance.

courses.name: Problems in Plant Science
courses.description: Not accepted as a substitute for any regularly scheduled course. Problems arranged with individual faculty member in specific matter area.

courses.name: Forest Pathology
courses.description: Provides basic understanding of biotic and abiotic agents which cause forest diseases, and current approaches to disease control.

courses.name: Biology of Fungi
courses.description: (same as BIO_SC 3510). The diverse roles of fungi in the biosphere will be explored by considering fungi we eat, fungi which destroy our food, fungi in folklore and fungi as global nutrient recyclers.

courses.name: Introductory Entomology
courses.description: (same as BIO_SC 3710). Emphasizes the role insects play in the scheme of life.  Topics include insect structure, development, diversity, ecology, communication and behavior, and management.
courses.prerequisites: Completion of 60 credit hours and one of the following: BIO_SC 1100 (or F_W 1100) or BIO_SC 1200, or BIO_SC 1500.

courses.name: Insect Diversity
courses.description: (same as BIO_SC 3715). Laboratory exercises emphasizing external insect anatomy, classification, and identification (to family level).  Preparation of an insect collection is required.

courses.name: Topics in Plant Science - Biological/Physical/Mathematics
courses.description: Initial offering of a course(s) in a specific subject matter area. Offered when proposed by a faculty member in that area of expertise.

courses.name: Soil Fertility and Plant Nutrition
courses.description: (same as SOIL 4313; cross-leveled with PLNT_S 7313, SOIL 7313). Explanation of principles of delivery of plant nutrients to plants, discussion of the role of each essential nutrient in crop plants and introduction to the management of soil amendments.

courses.name: Soil Fertility and Plant Nutrition Laboratory
courses.description: (same as SOIL 4314; cross-leveled with PLNT_S 7314, SOIL 7314). The application of elementary analytical procedures to the evaluation of the nutrient status of soils and crop plants.

courses.name: Crop Physiology
courses.description: (cross-leveled with PLNT_S 7315). Basic course on crop growth and development. Emphasis is on physiological processes and morphology of crop plants, and their application to crop breeding and management decisions.

courses.name: Molecular Plant Physiology
courses.description: (same as BIO_SC 4320; cross-leveled with PLNT_S 7320, BIO_SC 7320). Modern physiology of higher plants using common cultivated plants as examples.
courses.prerequisites: CHEM 1320 or CHEM 1330 and one of the following: BIO_SC  1500 or BIO_SC 1200.

courses.name: Field Crop Breeding
courses.description: (cross-leveled with PLNT_S 7325). Will introduce students to the application of genetics and the plant sciences to the breeding and improvement of self-pollinated field crops. Classical, current and innovative plant breeding techniques will be addressed.
courses.prerequisites: PLNT_S 2110 or PLNT_S 2125, and PLNT_S 3213 (or equivalent), and PLNT_S 3225 (or equivalent)

courses.name: Plant Breeding Theory
courses.description: (cross-leveled with PLNT_S 7330). Designed to provide a logical application of genetic concepts to mating and selection theory in general improvement of cross pollinated crops.

courses.name: Principles of Viticulture II
courses.description: (same as F_S 4340).  Environmental and biological factors influencing vine physiology and winegrape quality.  Irrigation, canopy management, pest and disease control, budgets and current trends in viticulture. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Principles of Viticulture and Winemaking
courses.description: (same as F_S 4345; cross-leveled with PLNT_S 7345, F_S 7345). This course will cover the basics needed by viticulturists and winemakers to understand grape vine growth and vineyard considerations along with winemaking principles. Viticultural topics will include grapevine growth and development, vineyard design and development, cultivar selection, grapevine propagation, training systems, and harvest and pruning. Winemaking topics will include sensory analysis of grapes, chemical, microbiological and technological aspects of winemaking, and the analytical methods used for juice and wine analysis. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Nursery Crop Production and Management
courses.description: Operations, methods used by wholesale, retail, landscape nurseries. Field problems, observational trips.

courses.name: Advanced Turfgrass Management
courses.description: (cross-leveled with PLNT_S 7355). Provides turfgrass majors a more informative and applicable look at mathematics of turfgrass management, application techniques, cultural practices, and soil/water relationships applicable to careers in golf course and sports turf management, lawn care, and professional grounds maintenance.

courses.name: Precision Agriculture Science and Technology
courses.description: (same as AG_S_M 4360, SOIL 4360; cross-leveled with PLNT_S 7360, AG_S_M 7360, SOIL 7360). Precision agriculture is an information-based approach to farming whereby variability is managed to optimize crop production and reduce environmental pollution. This course provides an overview of precision agriculture technologies (like GIS, GPS, remote sensing), mapping methods, and case studies illustrating decisions and management.
courses.prerequisites: PLNT_S 2100 or SOIL 2100, or PLNT_S 2110, or instructor's consent

courses.name: Greenhouse Crops Production
courses.description: (cross-leveled with PLNT_S 7365). Production management decision and commercial culture of the major floriculture crops.

courses.name: Problems in Plant Science
courses.description: Special problem in plant pathology designed for the minor program in Plant Pathology. Problems arranged on an individual student basis.

courses.name: Plant Anatomy
courses.description: (same as BIO_SC 4400; cross-leveled with PLNT_S 7400, BIO_SC 7400). Comparative structure, growth of meristems; development, structure of important cell types, tissues systems; comparative anatomy of stem, root, leaf.  Emphasizes anatomy of gymnosperms, angiosperms.  Includes lab. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Biology and Pathogenesis of Plant-Associated Microbes
courses.description: (cross-leveled with PLNT_S 7500). Diagnosis of diseases of plants caused by fungi, nematodes, viruses and bacteria  Environmental and genetic factors leading to disease development and strategies for disease management, including biotechnology.
courses.prerequisites: 5 hours from the following courses: BIO_SC 1010, BIO_SC 1020, BIO_SC 1030, BIO_SC 1100, BIO_SC 1200 or BIO_SC 1500; and completion of 60 credit hours.

courses.name: Environmental Microbiology
courses.description: Fundamental knowledge of selected microbial processes that are important in agriculture, environmental detoxification, and microbial biotechnology. Emphasis is on molecular, genetic and physiological aspects of nitrogen metabolism, bioconversions, antibiosis and biocontrol.

courses.name: Plant Biotechnology
courses.description: (cross-leveled with PLNT_S 7550). Principles of gene expression, metabolic pathway analysis and data mining, plant tissue culture and transformation, transgene integration and expression analysis, plant epigenome, emerging transgenic technologies, etc.
courses.prerequisites: PLNT_S 2125 and one of the following: PLNT_S 3213, or BIO_SC 2200 or BIO_SC 2300.

courses.name: Systematic Entomology
courses.description: (cross-leveled with PLNT_S 7710). Taxonomy of insects: emphasizes biology and classification of orders and suborders in lecture, and major families in lab.  Insect collection required.
courses.prerequisites: PLNT_S 3715 and one of the following: BIO_SC 1100 or BIO_SC 1500.

courses.name: Aquatic Entomology
courses.description: (cross-leveled with PLNT_S 7720).  Identification, life histories, ecology of aquatic insects.  Grading is based on lecture, lab, and a collection.  For students of wildlife, fisheries management, aquatic biology, advanced entomology.
courses.prerequisites: PLNT_S 3710 or PLNT_S 3715 or equivalent, or instructor's consent

courses.name: Insect Pest Management for Plant Protection
courses.description: (cross-leveled with PLNT_S 7730). History and concepts of Integrated Pest Management of insect pests, emphasizing complementary use of biological control, plant resistance, environmental manipulations, genetic manipulations, and selective use of insecticides.

courses.name: Internship in Plant Science
courses.description: Combines study, observation, and employment with an industry or government agency in area of agronomy or horticulture. Written and oral reports and faculty evaluation.
courses.prerequisites: Completion of 75 hours including two courses in department and instructor's consent

courses.name: Undergraduate Research in Plant Science
courses.description: Capstone experience consisting of investigations in Plant Science in support of an undergraduate thesis or special project portfolio.
courses.prerequisites: Completion of 75 credit hours and Plant Science Majors only

courses.name: Special Readings in Plant Pathology
courses.description: Independent readings and discussions of topics in entomology selected in consultation with supervising faculty member. Paper required.

courses.name: Readings in Molecular Ecology of Herbivory
courses.description: (cross-leveled with PLNT_S 7970). The application of molecular biology tools to the rich history of chemical, physiological, population, and multi-trophic ecology studies on plant herbivore interactions has made for an exciting, fast-paced field at the forefront of ecology, 'functional biology' and 'systems biology'. Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Advanced Landscape Design
courses.description: (cross-leveled with PLNT_S 7975). Development of project presentation techniques by analysis of the social, cultural, historical and ecological aspects of landscape design.

courses.name: Topics
courses.description: Initial offering of a course(s) in a specific subject matter area. Offered when proposed by a faculty member in that area of expertise.

courses.name: Problems
courses.description: Advanced studies not expected to terminate in thesis. Problems arranged with individual faculty member in specific matter area.

courses.name: Seminar
courses.description: In-depth development of advanced aspects of plant, insect, or microbial sciences through reviews of results of research in progress and current scientific publications. Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Nonthesis Research
courses.description: Original investigation not leading to preparation of thesis.

courses.name: Soil Fertility and Plant Nutrition
courses.description: (same as SOIL 7313; cross-leveled with PLNT_S 4313, SOIL 4313). Explanation of principles of delivery of plant nutrients to plants, discussion of the role of each essential nutrient in crop plants and introduction to the management of soil amendments.

courses.name: Soil Fertility and Plant Nutrition Laboratory
courses.description: (same as SOIL 7314; cross-leveled PLNT_S 4314, SOIL 4314). The application of elementary analytical procedures to the evaluation of the nutrient status of soils and crop plants.
courses.prerequisites: concurrent enrollment or previous completion of SOIL 4313 SOIL 7313

courses.name: Crop Physiology
courses.description: (cross-leveled with PLNT_S 4315). Basic course on crop growth and development. Emphasis is on physiological processes and morphology of crop plants, and their application to crop breeding and management decisions.

courses.name: Molecular Plant Physiology
courses.description: (same as BIO_SC 7320; cross-leveled with PLNT_S 4320, BIO_SC 4320). Modern physiology of higher plants using common cultivated plants as examples. May be taken with or without laboratory.
courses.prerequisites: BIO_SC 1500 or BIO_SC 1200 and five hours of chemistry

courses.name: Field Crop Breeding
courses.description: (cross-leveled with PLNT_S 4325). Will introduce students to the application of genetics and the plant sciences to the breeding and improvement of self-pollinated field crops. Classical, current and innovative plant breeding techniques will be addressed.
courses.prerequisites: PLNT_S 2110 or PLNT_S 2125, and PLNT_S 3213 (or equivalent), and PLNT_S 3225 (or equivalent)

courses.name: Plant Breeding Theory
courses.description: (cross-leveled with PLNT_S 4330). Designed to provide a logical application of genetic concepts to mating and selection theory in general improvement of cross pollinated crops.

courses.name: Principles of Viticulture and Winemaking
courses.description: (same as F_S 7345; cross-leveled with PLNT_S 4345, F_S 4345). This course will cover the basics needed by viticulturists and winemakers to understand grape vine growth and vineyard considerations along with winemaking principles. Viticultural topics will include grapevine growth and development, vineyard design and development, cultivar selection, grapevine propagation, training systems, and harvest and pruning. Winemaking topics will include sensory analysis of grapes, chemical, microbiological and technological aspects of winemaking, and the analytical methods used for juice and wine analysis. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Readings
courses.description: Individual study of assigned topics.

courses.name: Advanced Turfgrass Management
courses.description: (cross-leveled with PLNT_S 4355). Provides turfgrass majors a more informative and applicable look at mathematics of turfgrass management, application techniques, cultural practices, and soil/water relationships applicable to careers in golf course and sports turf management, lawn care, and professional grounds maintenance. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Precision Agriculture Science and Technology
courses.description: (same as AG_S_M 7360 and SOIL 7360; cross-leveled with PLNT_S 4360, AG_S_M 4360, SOIL 7360). Precision agriculture is an information-based approach to farming whereby variability is managed to optimize crop production and reduce environmental pollution. This course provides an overview of precision agriculture technologies (like GIS, GPS, remote sensing), mapping methods, and case studies illustrating decisions and management.

courses.name: Greenhouse Crops Production
courses.description: (cross-leveled with PLNT_S 4365). Production management decision and commercial culture of the major floriculture crops.

courses.name: Small Fruit and Vegetable Production
courses.description: Emphasizes production, management and marketing practices for small fruit and vegetable crops.

courses.name: Plant Anatomy
courses.description: (same as BIO_SC 7400; cross-leveled with PLNT_S 4400, BIO_SCI 4400). Comparative structure, growth of meristems; development, structure of important cell types, tissue systems; comparative anatomy of stem, root, leaf. Emphasized anatomy of gymnosperms, angiosperms. Includes lab. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Biology and Pathogenesis of Plant-Associated Microbes
courses.description: (cross-leveled with PLNT_S 4500). Diagnosis of disease of plants caused by fungi, nematodes, viruses and bacteria.  Environmental and genetic factors leading to disease development and strategies for disease management, including biotechnology.

courses.name: Plant Biotechnology
courses.description: (cross-leveled with PLNT_S 4550). Principles of gene expression, metabolic pathway analysis and data mining, plant tissue culture and transformation, transgene integration and expression analysis, plant epigenome, emerging transgenic technologies, etc.
courses.prerequisites: BIO_SC 2960 or equivalent; BIO_SC 2200 or equivalent; BIO_SCI 2300 or equivalent; PLNT_S 2125

courses.name: Systematic Entomology
courses.description: (cross-leveled with PLNT_S 4710). Taxonomy of insects: emphasizes biology and classification of orders and suborders in lecture, and major families in lab.  Insect collection required.
courses.prerequisites: PLNT_S 3710 and PLNT_S 3715 or 10 hours Biological Sciences

courses.name: Aquatic Entomology
courses.description: (cross-leveled with PLNT_S 4720). Identification, life histories, ecology of aquatic insects.  Grading is based on lecture, lab, and a collection.  For students of wildlife, fisheries management, aquatic biology, advanced entomology.
courses.prerequisites: PLNT_S 3710, PLNT_S 3715 or equivalent or instructor's consent

courses.name: Insect Pest Management for Plant Protection
courses.description: (cross-leveled with PLNT_S 4730).   History and concepts of Integrated Pest Management for insects pests, emphasizing complementary use of biological control, plant resistance, environmental manipulations, genetic manipulations, and selective use of insecticides.

courses.name: Principles of Insect Physiology
courses.description: Major concepts of insect physiology emphasizing functions of organ-systems sensory physiology hormones in development, nutrition.
courses.prerequisites: PLNT_S 3710, PLNT_S 3715 and PLNT_S 7810 or equivalent

courses.name: Readings in Plant Stress Biology
courses.description: Independent readings and discussion of recent research publications. Topics selected in consultation with supervisory faculty member.

courses.name: Readings in Molecular Ecology of Herbivory
courses.description: (cross-leveled with PLNT_S 4970).The application of molecular biology tools to the rich history of chemical, physiological, population, and multi-trophic ecology studies on plant herbivore interactions has made for an exciting, fast-paced field at the forefront of ecology, 'functional biology' and 'systems biology'. Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Advanced Landscape Design
courses.description: (cross-leveled with PLNT_S 4975). Development of project presentation techniques by analysis of the social, cultural, historical and ecological aspects of landscape design.

courses.name: Topics
courses.description: Instruction in specific subject matter areas in plant, insect or microbial sciences.

courses.name: Professionalism and Ethics
courses.description: Ethical issues in the conduct of scientific research including data integrity, plagiarism, and intellectual property.  Scientific writing, lab management, peer review and other professional skills for the life sciences. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Thesis Research
courses.description: Original investigations in plant, insect or microbial science in support of thesis for master's candidates.  Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Molecular Breeding
courses.description: Development of Molecular Breeding, Evolution of Transgenics, Transformation and Gene Transfer Methods, Transgenics in the Food Supply Genetics and Marker Technology, Genotyping Methods for Marker Assisted Selection (MAS, and Emerging Transgenic and Genotyping Technologies.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Introduction to Plant Metabolism
courses.description: (same as BIO_SC 8362 and BIOCHM 8362). This course is part of a series that aims to provide a solid conceptual foundation in interdisciplinary plant biology for graduate students with a research emphasis in plant biology.  This course examines the basic concepts and techniques used to understand plant metabolism.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Introduction to Molecular Cell Biology
courses.description: (same as BIOCHM 8365 and BIO_SC 8365). This course is part of a series that aims to provide a solid conceptual foundation in interdisciplinary plant biology for graduate students with a research emphasis on plant biology.  This course examines the basic concepts and techniques used to understand molecular cell biology.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Advanced Weed Science
courses.description: Discussion of herbicide physiology and fate in the environment, current development in weed science theory and methodology, and application of analytical procedures in weed research.

courses.name: Herbicide Mode of Action and Symptomology
courses.description: Designed for graduate students to gain an understanding of the in-depth processes by which herbicides interrupt normal plant growth and development at a tissue, cellular, and enzymatic level while learning to diagnose visual symptoms associated with herbicide injury.  Course maybe repeated for credit.  Graded on A-F basis.

courses.name: Introduction to Bioinformatics Programming
courses.description: (same as AN_SCI 8430). This course provides the basics of programming and database development to students in the life sciences who have little prior programming experience. It covers Unix/Linux, Perl, MySQL, the relational database design process, and common data formats used in genome informatics. Students will learn how programming skills can enhance their ability to analyze large biological datasets, and will gain hands on experience with examples focused on genomics and bioinformatics. Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.recommendation: Undergraduate or graduate course in Genetics

courses.name: Introduction to Plant Stress Biology
courses.description: (same as BIO_SC 8505) This course is part of a series that aims to provide a solid conceptual foundation to interdisciplinary plant biology for graduate students with a research emphasis in plant biology.  This course examines the basic concepts and techniques used to understand plant stress biology.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Research with Plant Stress Agents
courses.description: Students will learn key research strategies for abiotic and biotic plant stress agents. Students will complete two focused hands-on projects. Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: PLNT_S 7500 and PLNT_S 7510 or PLNT_S 7315, or PLNT_S 7320, or equivalent

courses.name: Ecological and Evolutionary Genomics
courses.description: (same as BIO_SC 8650).  This course is designed to give a background in evolution and then explore an exciting new field:  Ecological and evolutionary genomics.  We will study genes that affect fitness and how whole genomes evolve.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Insect Behavior
courses.description: An examination of the breadth of behaviors found in insects, such as orientation mechanisms, communication, dispersal and migration, defensive mechanisms, lost location, feeding strategies, pollination, courtship and reproduction, and social behavior.
courses.prerequisites: PLNT_S 3710 and PLNT_S 3715 or 10 hours of Biological Sciences

courses.name: Topics
courses.description: Instruction in specific subject matter areas in plant, insect or microbial sciences.

courses.name: Seminar in Plant Science
courses.description: In-depth development of advanced aspects of plant, insect and microbial sciences through reviews of results of research in progress and current scientific publications. Graded on A-F or S/U basis dependent on section.

courses.name: Dissertation Research
courses.description: Original investigations in plant, insect or microbial science in support of dissertation for doctoral candidates. Graded on a S/U basis only.

courses.name: Ecology of Grazing Lands Systems
courses.description: Students travel to grazing lands ecosystems to learn: the components and function of grazing lands; research techniques in soil-plant-animal research; forage-livestock ecology; and the role of forages in conservation practices, wildlife habitat, and sustainable agriculture.

courses.name: Advanced Plant Physiology
courses.description: Advanced course in the physiology of plant growth and development. Discussion of current and classical studies in plant physiology with emphasis on responses to environmental variation.
courses.prerequisites: PLNT_S 4315 or PLNT_S 4320 or equivalent.  Instructor's consent required

courses.name: Applied Quantitative and Statistical Genetics
courses.description: Estimation of genetic effects using means and variances, diallel analysis, environmental stability responses, index selection, and gain from selection.
courses.prerequisites: PLNT_S 4330,  STAT 4510, STAT 4530, AN_SCI 9423, or equivalent

courses.name: Genetics of Plant-Microorganism Interaction
courses.description: Molecular and general genetics of the interactions between plants and pathogenic or symbiotic microorganisms.
courses.prerequisites: PLNT_S 7500 and PLNT_S 7510, one course each in Biochemistry and Genetics

courses.name: Insect Ecology
courses.description: Ecological aspects of insect populations and communities including population dynamics, predator-prey interactions, competition, diversity and stability. Quantitative methods are emphasized.
courses.prerequisites: PLNT_S 3710 and PLNT_S 3715, STAT 1400 and BIO_SC 3650 or instructor's consent
